fields.description: The QA team discovered this and then I saw it as well running the console behind an ELB and doing load testing. I generated a lot of requests over a time and eventually saw problems rendering the login page (screen-shots attached). I looked at the console servers and finding nothing in logs, tried logging into those directly. The console servers themselves respond properly and serve up full pages. QA team confirms this scenario as well.
fields.summary: document upgrade process when deploying console at scale

comments.body:
I'm inspecting page assets in Chrome's dev tools. I see some css and javascript is served just fine. In other cases, I'm seeing some javascript assets showing as a HTML response that contains this: {code}

404 Not Found

The resource you have requested was not found.

{code} This tells me that the console server provided this "bad" content. So, I disabled caching in the dev tools and reloaded the page. Bingo! It renders properly now and I can login and use the console! I think this may kick back to the console team to debug now.

I got the problem to happen again. I noticed it after running load test on a single instance behind an ELB overnight, then adding a 2nd instance this morning. One of those instances is returning a 404 on an angular-sanitize.min.js file, repeatably. It is the older of the instances which is returning the 404 instead of the file.

I think I got to the bottom of this issue. Yesterday and today, the 2nd instance had been added on a new day. Therefore, that new instance got the nightly packages. The big deal here is that the static assets are served with a url path that includes the version, to avoid upgrade issues with caching older versions of files. It's normal cache-busting between versions of software.

One server provided the page that included links to static assets. Some of those assets were requested from 1 server, some from the other. Both should be able to serve them, but they both had a different static path they knew to be right and if they got the wrong static path, 404.

Moral of the story, update all of your console instances at once in a scaling group behind an ELB! [~tvo], we ought to document this for the console admin!

Here's a workaround to this:
 - before starting an upgrade in a console group, turn on session stickyness in the ELB: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/elb-sticky-sessions.html
 - do your rolling upgrade (start killing old instances in the console group and let them be replaced, is 1 strategy)
 - turn off session stickyness after all old instances are replaced.

This ensures all requests go to the same host for individual users for the time where the console group is non-homogeneous.
Yes, this is inline with what we have seen on QA cloud. I think this is the cause.
[~ccassler], please verify steps and then reassign to [~tvo]

To test, simply set up console behind ELB w/ 1 instance using nightly build. Let it run till the next day.
Then configure session stickyness.
Install another instance behind ELB with new nightly packages.
See that user can use the application without seeing the rendering problem we had due to missing static resources.
shut down 1st instance and turn off session stickyness (in that order) and things should remain perfectly operational.

It might take me a couple of days to retest this.  I have only reproduced this once in the shared-setup-1 and it is currently not happening.  I'm going to try to reproduce the bug in my own environment before trying the fix.  I want to make sure I have consistent breakage before I try the solution.

I had a console w/ 2 instances in a scaling group running since yesterday, so increased my scaling group by 1 this morning. As soon as that 3rd instance came on-line, the problem re-occurred. I killed the new instance (then set the scaling group down to 2, as soon as possible). The pages started rendering properly after that.

[~dkavanagh]: I was able to reproduce this using the following steps:
# WITHOUT using session stickiness, I configured my ELB to use one instance and let it run overnight with a load script hitting it (the load script probably isn't necessary)
# I then added a second instance to the ELB and let it become healthy
# I upgraded eucaconsole on the second instance that was just added
# After the upgrade completed, I refreshed the browser and the GUI was in the unstable state described in this ticket
# I then configured session stickiness using the following command: 'eulb-create-lb-cookie-stickiness-policy -e 60 -p update-console console-lb'
# I then upgraded the first instance to the latest overnight eucaconsole build
# Once the upgrade finished, I refreshed the browser and the GUI returned back to a normal state.

So the session stickiness appears to be working.  The next test I would like to try is to leave session stickiness on and the run another upgrade on just one instance and see if the original problem returns.

[~dkavanagh]: I reproduced this scenario again, however, I wasn't using session stickiness and the problem still went away after updating both instances with the latest console.  So perhaps session stickiness isn't the solution, unless this was a coincidence?  Perhaps there's a probability that updating both instances won't always solve the problem unless session stickiness is enabled?  What do you think?

Let's discuss in IRC. I'd want to know under what conditions the problem occurred. The way your comment is worded, something happened, and after updating both instances, things were better. I'm not sure why you think updating both instances won't help when you said it did?

[~dkavanagh], [~tvo]: So based on my last comment, It doesn't appear that session stickiness has any effect on controlling the UX experience for consoles with different versions.  We can trouble-shoot this further but I wonder if the short-term solution should be to just make sure to document that ALL consoles have the same version on every eucaconsole instance behind an ELB or bad things can happen.
How would you guys like me to document this? It doesn't look like we've come to a conclusion, other than a simple note somewhere.
I need to chat w/ Casey about session stickyness. [~tvo], did you get the deployment steps on the linked ticket into a doc somewhere?
[~dkavanagh]: no not yet, that's why I commented yesterday asking if there was a definitive conclusion so that I could.
Sent out to David and Casey for initial review and to solicit additional material..
